title: The Tea Girl of Hummingbird Lane
review: A staggering amount of research went into this novel about tea, rural China, the Akha people, and the adoption of Chinese girls to America. Lisa See created masterful blend of fact and fiction that grips you to the end.

title: The Bean Trees
review: Liked it overall, but wasn't fully pulled into the story. It's nice to dip your feet into the water sometimes without fully diving in, soaking up the things that move you and skimming over those that don't.

title: The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue
review: A wildly creative journey through time and memories. Not altogether unpredictable, but page-turning enough to stay interesting, with some really beautiful metaphors sprinkled through on creativity, art, and belonging.

title: Upstream: The Quest to Solve Problems Before They Happen
review: This book will make you feel simultaneously inspired and outraged: inspired by the hope of enacting real change through early intervention, and outrage at the widespread short-sightedness of America's health system. Upstream will change the way you think about problem solving.

title: Envisioning Information
review: An interesting foray into the history and strategy of dense-data design. A few practical notes, but mostly an academic analysis of how to encode visuals with information.

title: Habibi
review: My brain cannot comprehend how much work went into this graphics novel. Every page is covered with painstaking detail and beauty. Learned a lot about Islamic history and mythology.

title: Blankets
review: Pure visual poetry. Craig Thompson writes with a gentle lyricism and illustrates in a style both mystical and raw. My first graphic novel, and I loved every page.

title: Eat a Peach
review: In his memoir, Chang talks about the power of paradox constantly: it's power to make good food, spark creativity, upend long-standing systems. But the biggest paradox seemed to be Chang himself, both showy and self-deprecating, cruel and sympathetic, ruthless and compassionate. Whatever your opinion, he's an unforgettable character in food that had changed restaurants in America forever.

title: Just Food: Where Locavores Get it Wrong and How We Can Truly Eat Responsibly
review: McWilliams offers a balanced argument for how to create a truly sustainable and just food economy. That being said, his most powerful points are dampened by his obvious distaste for the locavore movement; some of this is well deserved, but the belittling tone creates a unnecessary dichotomy. To create sustainable systems we need a both/AND approach, not either/or. More local AND more access to affordable, conventional foods. Overall I will take some new and innovative ideas from this book though: the importance of Lifecycle Assessments, short sightedness of food miles, and the promise of aquaculture and aquaponics to name a few highlights.

title: Healing Power of Color
review: Was not what I expected...started out interesting with some of the history behind color use in ancient civilizations. Then it got into the real point of the book, which is chakric color healing...guess I should have read the title literally instead of figuratively.

title: Everything I Never Told You
review: A moving story about family, the expectations of parents, forgotten dreams, and the fog of grief that follows loss. As with "Little Fires Everywhere", Ng paints the portrait of non-white family life with exceptional clarity and beauty, weaving the concept of felt "otherness" into every page.

title: The Immortalists
review: Four stories woven into the thread of a single family plagued by their own sense of destiny, loss, and belonging. Colorful and dark.

title: The Year of Less
review: Cait challenges herself to not buy anything extra for a year, then writes about her struggles and lessons learned along the way. A simple book, with a simple (if a sometimes a bit naiive) message: less is often more.

title: Little Fires Everywhere
review: This book has so many layers: race, class, privelege, motherhood, trust. A gripping story. Still thinking about it.

title: Heavy: An American Memoir
review: An absolutely beautiful piece of literature: the prose, rhythm, memories, confessions, all the words that suck you into a story that is not your own. It's all heavy, and you feel it, and the weight stays with you. Laymon is a genius.

title: Stamped: Racism, Antiracism, and You
review: Reynolds brings a new voice to the history of the Black struggle in America, one that is crisp, concise, and rhythmic. An engaging entry into the complex past of race and the antiracist movement.

title: In Defense of Food: An Eater's Manifesto
review: Pollan reveals the the facade of nutrtionism for what it really is: food capitalism. We do not need food products; we need food. Pollan's manifesto feels elegant in simplicity, romantic in its reverence for vegetables, and thoroughly well researched. An uncomplicated mantra to shop by: "eat food. Not too much. Mostly plants."

title: White Fragility: Why It’s So Hard for White People to Talk About Racism
review: This book pulls no punches, and necessarily so. DiAngelo explains how to sit with the discomfort of white supremacy culture and then do something about it.

title: The Restaurant at the End of the Universe: (Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #2)
review: A string of rambling, rabbit holes filled with characters trying to out-wit each other with gallows humor. Like SNL, but without ya know, the laughs.

title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy: (Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #1)
review: I think maybe I missed something...most of the jokes/banter didn't fall on me. And if you don't read this for the jokes/banter, what else is there really?

title: Between the World and Me
review: A poetic, raw, and unapologetic window into the Black experience. Coates' prose is masterful.

title: Dandelions
review: Strange and splintered, this unfinished novel feels more like a loosely woven series of poems than a story. Even without closure, something still stays with you at the end.

title: Cloud Atlas
review: The breadth of styles, stories, language and character in this single book is very impressive. Though it took hundreds of pages to adopt any sort of plot, the final 10 percent is virtuosic. Mitchell is uniquely talented to weave together such different stories into a recurring question: ".. what is any ocean but a multitude of drops?"

title: Martin Dressler: The Tale of an American Dreamer
review: Brilliantly captures the often self-destructive restlessness of American progress.

title: The Colossus and Other Poems
review: Dark, haunting, and beautiful. Plath's poems pulled me into a world of gray, where death was not something to be feared but observed.

title: Utopia for Realists: How We Can Build the Ideal World
topics: basic income, health care, democratic socialism
review: Brennan's ideas are bold and unapologetically ambitious. It can be hard to keep up with all the studies referenced, but his writing is compelling enough to make you think twice. Big ideas have changed the world before; Brennan gives a strong case for ideas that can change the world now.

title: The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind, and Body in the Healing of Trauma
review: An insightful and research heavy journey into the intrinsic link between body and mind. Learned quite a bit, but almost too many studies, examples, stories, etc to remember everything by the end. A dense read.

title: A Thousand Splendid Suns
review: Heartbreaking, brutal, and unapologetically raw. But still, there is hope. Hosseini is a masterful storyteller.

title: The Souls of Black Folk
review: Du Bois writes with sharp eloquence. His journalism reads like poetry. His critique of the post-slavery South spares no punches. A must read for understanding the reconstruction era and transition from slavery to Jim Crow.

title: Maeve in America: Essays by a Girl from Somewhere Else
review: This memoir made me chuckle in a few spots, but I wouldn't call it hilarious. Most essays felt a bit too self-involved (which to be fair, is fundamental to being a memoir). Was hoping for better, but not disappointed that I read it.

title: Comedy Sex God
review: Hilarious, unfiltered, mystical magic. Pete Holmes hit me in the feels and now I can't stop asking: "what is this?"

title: The Bletchley Girls
review: An ambitious attempt to tell the hidden stories of 15 women working to break German codes in the war. Too ambitious. 15 different storylines was way too many for this style of writing. The history was fascinating but found myself lost in the monitors my of details among 15 different lives.

title: The Family Fang
review: Disorienting, bizarre, erratic and touching. I was surprised by The Family Fang in all of the best ways.

title: The Overstory
review: A truly breathtaking story—mythical, scientific, philosophical, and deeply moving. Powers weaves in so many facts about trees and forests that I often forgot I was reading fiction; the level of research, from how trees can speak to each other to adapting real protest events in the Northwest Timber Wars, makes the story even more compelling. I will never look at trees the same again.

title: The Scarlet Letter
review: I get that it's a classic, but even so: this book was repetitive and uninspired. Themes were interesting but lacked the subtlety and delivery to make them impactful. My biggest takeaway is that Puritans were the worst.

title: The Year of Living Danishly: Uncovering the Secrets of the World's Happiest Country
review: Funny, witty, and informative. Maybe should move to Denmark?

title: An Artist of the Floating World
review: A story of memory, loss, and looking back on a life lived with conviction, but at the wrong time.

title: The Road
review: Dark and devastatingly beautiful.
